DIV1.P: REASONS AGAINST FIGHTING. BEING An ENQUIRY into this Great Debate, Whether it is Safe for Her MAJESTY, or Her MINISTRY, to Venture an Engagement with the FRENCH, considering the Present Behaviour of the ALLIES.
The Resolution of the House of Commons, on Wednesday, May 28. 1712.

Resolved, That this House hath an entire Confidence i Her Majesties most Gracious Promise to communicate to Her Parliament the Terms of the Peace before the same shall be concluded; and that they will support Her Majesty in obtaining an Honourable and Safe Peace, against all such Persons, either at Home or Abroad, who have endeavour'd, or shall endeavour, to obstruct the same.
Her Majesty's most Gracious Answer to this Resolution, Friday, May 30. 1712.

Gentlemen, I thank you most Heartily for this Resolution, which is Dutiful to Me, Honest to Our Country, and very Seasonable at this Time, when so many Artifices are used to obstruct a Good Peace, or to force one Disadvantageous to Britain.
Printed in the Year 1712. Price 6 d.

DIV1.HEAD: REASONS AGAINST FIGHTING: OR, Some Account why the Confederates could not expect the British Army should join with them whenever they thought fit to attack the French.
DIV1.P:
THE Town having been most ma∣liciously amused with an Account in a Printed Postscript, which, (as it is there managed and related,) is calculated to lay as much Reproach on the British Na∣tion, and on Her Majesty, as is possible; it cannot but be an acceptable Work to all that have any Regard to the Honour of their Countrey, or their Queen, to examine into an Affair of such a Nature, and state the same to the People, that they may not be
imposed upon by false Glosses, and malici∣ous Constructions. In our first Entrance into the Merits of this Cause, we shall save a great deal of Fending and Proving about the Matter of Fact, and therefore without enquiring into the Truth of the Relation, which is believed to be a meer Forgery of the Scotchman who writes that Paper, whose Talent of Lying is so well known to Mankind; yet to deal the better with him and his Party, we will for once suppose here all his Relation to be right, and shall argue from it as if it were so, (viz.) I am no Braggadocio nor Gascon, but do assure you, that I never promised myself more from a Day of Battle than I did from this; and I prepared myself to fight, when—refus'd to Second me. I ask'd him, what he did there then? He told me, he came to fight, but that he had re∣ceiv'd Orders, which he shew'd me, not to act offensively against the Army of France.

Supposing this then to be true, who are they that make Complaint? This Author says, many do; it is hoped it is not our good Friends and Confederates the Dutch: Many Reasons concur to move us to hope thus of them: Principally that it was for some Ages the Practice of that wise and wary People, with us, and with all their Allies, it hath been so often, and so loudly complained of by the English Court in former Days, and by their other Confederates that the Dutch sent their Deputies into the Army to con∣troul
their Generals; and such fatal Effects have been found to be the Consequence of it, that surely it can never be the Dutch that should complain of being abandoned, but they should look back to their former Con∣duct in the like Cases, of which the History of those Days is full. If his Grace the Duke of Marlborough pleaseth to give an Account of the many Occasions in which this Con∣duct of the States-General hath been fatal to King William, in his Wars in Flanders, there will be but too many Instances of the like, more especially beginning at the Siege of Bonne in the Year 1674, or there∣abouts.

If his Grace the Duke of Marlborough doth not think fit to give his Evidence in this Case, the Opponents being at this Time something Allied to his Grace's Interest, there are not wanting living Witnesses to prove it, when the States Field-Deputies refused to let the Dutch Forces fight, as especially during the first Part of the late War, at the Business of Steenkirk, at Beau∣mont, before that at the long March to gain the French Lines, when the late Dauphin commanded the French Army; also at the first Siege of Mons by the French, at the first Siege of Namure, and many more In∣stances of like Nature: It was not without very great Difficulty that the late King William obtain'd so entire a Confidence to be placed in him by the Dutch, as to have
the Command of the Army compleatly in himself. Soon as the King was dead, al∣though they have committed the Command of their Troops to the Duke of MarlBorough, to Prince Eugene, and the like Great Gene∣rals, yet is it plain it is all Subject, and un∣der Orders, to the Five Dutch Field-Dep∣ties, who have their Voices in every Coun∣cil of War; and who, though they have no Command in the Army, yet have a Universal Command over the whole Army. Nor can the General Act, or March, much less Fight, if they please to put in their Ne∣gative at a Council of War. If it is al∣ledged that they never gave their Negative upon any probable Action, it shall be an∣swered in many Particulars, but not to dis∣pute that; it is certain they are empowered to give a Negative most effectually, in Case of which Negative the Troops would not act, no although their General should command them. And what shall we say, that after and notwithstanding this, the Queen should have less Authority to act than the Dutch; that Her Majesty should not have Power to prevent the Effusion of Blood, when she may see the Conclusion of a Peace so easie, if the Confederates would hear Reason; that there should be no Ne∣cessity of such a Butchery, as that of Blareg∣nies, to gain perhaps the bare Retreat of the French, and perhaps not that.

But to wave that Part till afterward, and return to what was mentioned before, after the P—of O—was come to be ad∣vanced to the British hrones, and by his Successes in England and eland had made himself more popular in Holland than before, the Dutch finding also that the English were ill satisfied with the Diffidence the States had always shewn in the Trusts of their Army, came at last into the Measures the King had laid before them, and committed their Forces to the King, with a Discretio∣nary Power to Fight, or not to Fight, when he thought fit. It should not be forgotten that the States were moved to this, by see∣ing the King at the Head of a Powerful Army of his own Troops, entirely com∣manding the Imperial and Spanish Armies; and that if they should refuse to give up their Troops to him, he would be in a Con∣dition to sight the French, or undertake some Siege without their Help that their Troops would not only lose the Honour, but the States themselves should be lessened in the Figure they made in the Confederacy; that as their Troops should perhaps be scarcely in the Action, so neither would their Inte∣rests be equally taken Care of in case of any Advantages obtained. These, and many more, were the Arguments which really brought in the States-General to consent to take off their Field-Deyuties from the Ar∣my,
and leave the King entirely to act as he should think fit.

Those People who remember any Thing of what is behind them cannot forget how great a Point it was thought gained when the Dutch were brought to do thus; how the Success, which was promised to Affairs, encouraged the Parliament and People to go on more warmly in the Prosecution of the War, because the Dutch had now consent∣ed to take away their Restraints: After the Death of the King, as well when the Ar∣mies were commanded by Monsieur Over∣kirk as by the Duke of Marlborough himself, the said Dutch Deputies were replaced in their Army; on all Occasions they were ad∣mitted to sit in the Councils of War, and if they did not give their Assent no Action of Moment could be undertaken; farther, the States have kept such a Negative upon the Actions in the Field, as that even when the Council of War have often resolved on this or that, those Resolutions have been first sent to the Hague for the Approbation of the States themselves before they could be put in Practice, though the Field-Deputies have been consenting to it before in the Army. Such hath been the Power the States-General have always reserved in their Hands to govern and restrain the Af∣fairs of the Army and the War, by which, in Effect, they had the Command of the British Armies and Generals; the Queen
had the Name indeed of being at the Head of the Confederacy, and had the Power to put a General of Her own in the Command over Her own Troops; but even Her Ma∣jesty, and all Her Generals and Forces, were so far under the Command of the Dutch, and so far to be governed by the Councils at the Hague, that nothing could be done without first applying to the said States, or their Deputies, for their Consent: Thus we willingly submitted to having gi∣ven ourselves up to Dutch Councils, it is not to be wonder'd that this, and more, was stooped to by such People as were come into a State of Pupilage to the States; and who left both the Direction of the War, and the Management of the Peace, to them, as if their own Nation had no Interest or Concern in it, other than to receive their Orders from their High Mightinesses: Whether it is more wonderful that any Peo∣ple should thus Sacrifice their Countries In∣terest to a Selfish Neighbour, and with a profound and implicit Submission should give themselves over to the Management of a Foreign Nation? Or that the same People should now complain that Her Ma∣jesty assumes a little Her Right of judging when it is Right or Safe to hazard Battle, or not, as well as the Dutch. It seems to some that the Dutch have taken this Part upon them so long, that it should now be challeng∣ed as their due; and that the Exclusion of the
Queen of Great-Britain is most Righteous, that the States alone should have a Negative Voice in the Field▪ that the English Generals were never to Fight but when the Dutch gave them Leave, and were always to fight when they, the Dutch, proposed it: It is counted as an Aggravation in the present Case, that Prince Eugene was for Fighting the French, and to Crown all, the Dutch Deputies had consented; a Mighty Argument! What is the Infe∣rence? Then it was a most Heinous Offence that our General had not Orders to comply; so that the British Forces must Bleed, and Die, and March, and Fight, or lye Still, just as Prince Eugene and the Dutch Depu∣ties think fit that whenever these, for the carrying on their Separate Views, think fit to attack the French Army, tho' entrench'd up to the Teeth, fortified and posted to Ad∣vantage, the British Troops, like Obedient Slaves, must fall on with the greatest Ha∣zard; for it is well known that Her Ma∣jesties Troops are never failed of the Posts of Danger, and the Hotest and most Despe∣rate of the Service. On the other Hand, if the Advantages which offer, however great, are accepted by the British Generals, unless the Dutch please to join their Assent: Our Men can on no Account embrace the Opportunity; there are Numberless Exam∣ples of this Kind to be given but we esteem it so known a Truth in the Army, and eve∣rywhere else, that it is needless to mention
any more what is so Universally known: How then comes it to be surprizing to the People here that Her Majesty should, when she sees Cause, assume that Authority in the Army which the Dutch have so avowedly practised? And why is not Her Majesty as much of Right empowered to do this when her own Affairs require it, as the States-General have been when their Affairs have likewise re∣quired it? Observe here, the Dispute in this Part has no Relation to the Reasons why Her Majesty declines hazarding a Bat∣tle with the French; but to the Right Her Majesty has when Her own Affairs make it reasonable upon any Score to Fight, or not to Fight, as She thinks fit.

Having thus made a Protest in Her Majesty's Name for the Reservation to Her∣self, the guiding of Her own Affairs, it comes in order to examine the Case before us, which has given so great an Occasion of Discourse, viz. That the Queen has given Orders to Her Generals not to Fight with the French, or to undertake any Siege; we shall be wary in saying that there might be, or that there are, Reasons why it might not be Safe for Her Majesty to hazard Her Troops, and that there may be good Reasons why, as Cases stand, the Queen should not venture a Battle in Conjun∣ction with the Allies, who are now in the Field with Her: But this may be said Safely, that whereas the Endeavours of a Party
among us to render the Ministry here, and the Management of Affairs in the British Court, suspected to the Allies, and that those wicked Designs have had but too much Success; so that great Misunderstandings, scandalous Misrepresentations, and Inve∣ctives, have too much supplied the Place of the usual mutual Confidence and Affecti∣on which was formerly established, and ought now to have been cultivated between Her Britannic Majesty and Her Allies; it cannot be supposed that in this Case the same Harmony, the same Unity, the same Con∣fidence, could be between them as it were to be wished; and therefore while that Confidence on both Sides hath been so Art∣fully lessened it cannot be expected, espe∣cially by that Side, who have so openly profest their Jealousie and Dissatisfaction, that the other should with the like Freedom, as on former Occasions, hazard with them in so Nice and so Critical an Affair as that of a General Battle.

This is not all, but it is not unknown of what Consequence the least Blow or Disap∣pointment in Case of Action might be to Her Majesty's Affairs; the Party here have not been silent in their Malicious Expecta∣tions, and have not scrupled to let us know that they had some Hopes in a Disappoint∣ment; they have been heard to say that One Defeat of the Army, One Battle in the Field, would ruin the present Ministry, and
fright the Queen into other Measures: As these are the known Hopes of this Party, and that the Secret Correspondence between them, and some Leading Men Abroad, who have it much in their Power to do either Good or Hurt in a Day of Battle, is also known, it may not be an ill-grounded Caution, that we should be backward to hazard a Battle with the Enemy, while in Conjunction with some who entertain a strict Confederacy with that Party here, who own, as above, that their Hopes are founded upon a Supposition of the Army receiving a Defeat Abroad: It is suggested that this is Supposititious, that no such Thoughts have been entertain'd here, and that our Confederates are not capable of entertaining any Thing so Disho∣nourable, nor could practise the Thing without Ruin and Destruction to them∣selves: This may have many Answers to it, all of them significant of the Thing, and justifying the Conduct of a Nation in such a Case. 1. That if these People here have no such Thoughts, as perhaps some among them may abhor so wicked a Practice; but why do they speak it in their own Dis∣course? Why do they please themselves with the talking of it? Do their Tongues speak what their Hearts never thought? It may be too true of them, that they think little, and might talk of small matters with∣out Meaning, but Capital Mischiefs never hang on the Tongue but when they are
dictated from the Heart; why should they talk thus? Would they be thought more Wicked than they are? Or would they talk what they did not intend, on Purpose, and with Design, to make themselves be suspect∣ed? Have we not heard them in the Public Coffee-houses say on the last Proclaimed Fast that they did not know how to keep it, that they did not know whether they should pray for Success upon our Armies, yea, or no? Or whether it were not as good that we should be beaten Abroad, that it might bring us to our Senses at Home; that One Battle lost would ruin the Ministry, and blow them all up, and such Talk as this; nay, have we not many so far exasperated, that will stop their Ears, or sit down in the midst of the Public Prayers, when the Minister is praying for the best of Blessings upon the Queen, and for Success to Her Majesty's Forces both at Sea and Land? They treat Her Majesty with more Freedom in their Cups, and long ago have they left off Tost∣ing a Health to the Generals, or Success to our Arms; while this Principle prevails, let any one judge whether it is Safe for us to venture an Engagement, tho' with an Ene∣my less Considerable, and less Dangerous, than the French, while thus Circum∣stanc'd at Home, and while these People boast of their strict Alliance, and close Friendship Abroad, with such People, up∣on whose Conduct the Sum of Affairs very much depends.

This is not to be construed as a Reflecti∣on on the Fidelity of the Allies, or a De∣claration that there is any such Thing as a Distrust on the Part of the British Court of the Justice or Faithfulness of the Confede∣rates▪ but it must be acknowledged by any unbyaed Judgment that these People have done what is their possible to create such a Jealousie: After such Notices of their Minds at Home, and Boasts of their In∣fluence Abroad, a Ministry, less wary, and less penetrating, than ours, might be well justified in resolving to Risque nothing with them: This is most sure, that they would be most inexcusable, who after such Warn∣ings should venture a Thing of so great a Consequence as a Battle, on a Disappoint∣ment wherein they had an Assurance that so much of the Hopes of their Enemies did depend. History might be brought to give Evidence in this Case, where in Affairs less Critical than these Cautions have been taken, and Measures of Safety pursued, on the least Discovery of the Secret Designs of Parties among the Confederate Troops.

It may be needful to say something here to the Objection following, (viz.) that this cannot be Rational to suspect, because it cannot be practised but at the Ruin of the Confederates: But many Instances have been given in the World of Armies driven to Exigences, by being deserted or forsaken in the Time of Action by their
Friends, without giving the Enemy Oppor∣tunity to break in upon the Parties who have so for saken them, of any where to hurt them: There have not wanted Instances of this, even between the same Parties we are speak∣ing of, when in the Sea-fight between the Confederate Fleet and the French Fleet, off of Beachy-Head, in the Year 1690, when the Dutch Admirals complained of their being forsaken and betrayed by the English Ad∣mirals, and left to the Mercy of the French Fleet, while the English made their Retreat in the best Manner they could, that by this Means the English Navy were preserved, and the Dutch were defeated, great part of their Squadron burnt and destroyed, or taken by the French, and the rest of the Fleet, being English, made off: This was afterwards brought before the King, and the Dutch Admirals complaining, threatned, that unless they had Satisfaction they would never hazard a Fight in Con∣juction with the English any more.

This is brought but as a parallel Case, for upon Examination no Treachery was found in the ase at all, but the Eng∣lish Admiral thought the Inequality too great to venture a general Engagement; likewife in this Case we may be justly said to be Uneasie, and not think ourselves Safe, while isunderstandings and Jealousies are fomented between us and our Allies: Whe∣ther we are really dissatisfied in the Fideli∣ty
of the Parties, or no; but be those Dis∣satisfactions of what Kind soever, it cannot be Prudence for us to run the Hazards that in other Cases might be done.

But to leave this ungrateful Part of the Subject, it is not said, or suggested here, that any Design was formed that might look like abandoning, or betraying, yet do many other Circumstances concur to make it reasonable that they should not Fight; that it is Her Majesty's Desire, and also the Desire of all Her Faithful Subjects, that a Good and Lasting Peace should be made, has been openly declared; what else has a Negotiation been set on Foot for? Her Majesty has other Work to do in the World than to amuse the Nations Abroad, or Her Subjects at Home, with a Treaty, if a Peace had not been Her Design: This is not a Thing to be dallied with, if the Pious and Christian Design of the Queen meets with Opposition from Parties, whose Views are known to be the Confusion of their Country, yet Her Majesty persists in Her Resolutions of making Peace: This brings us Home to the Teeth of the Party, and will expose their Scandalous Practices, and they may value themselves upon it when they please, it will be but shewing their own Nakedness to Posterity.

Her Majesty having, with mighty Struggling and Opposition, obtained a Treaty, and Plenipotentiaries from most of
the Confederates to meet for that Purpose▪ New Intrigues were immediately set or Foot to render all the Meetings and Conferences on the Grand Affair Abortive, a to come to nothing; to this Purpose, and the Measures for it being concerted, th Emperor on a sudden sends his Plenipotentiaries to the Congress, which he had resolved never to do before; it is to be observed, that no sooner were those Plenipotentiaries arrived, but a New Scene be∣gan to appear, and a different Part was acted from what they were acting before▪ for as they answered Cavaillierly, that they would never send any Ministers to the Meeting, or take any Notice of it, all on a sudden they were not only come to the Congress, but New Conferences, and New Measures, appear'd; the Imperial Mini∣sters were every Day at the Hague, there they conferr'd singly with other People▪ immediately the Subject of the Peace be∣came the Jest of the Place: The Earl of Strafford, the British Envoy and Plenipo∣tentiary, was Treated after a different and uncommon Manner, and all the Councils the Gentlemen had on that Affair discover∣ed an Inclination rather to prevent than promote a Peace, as the properest Scheme to carry on the Designs of their Party, which could not stand, or hope for it, but by carrying on the War.

Thus they put off the Time, and sus∣pended the Prosecution of the Peace, as if they had a Certainty that the Armies would join, that the Campaign would begin, and so the Treaty would be cut in Two by the Sword; believing that if they could get the Two Armies into Action the Treaty would of Course be broken off.

Now Her Majesty disappointed them All by coming to this Happy Resolu∣tion, (viz.) “If ye will not treat of Peace, neither will I carry on the War; if all that can be expected by the War may be obtained by a Treaty of Peace, I cannot satisfie myself to let any more Blood be shed when it may upon so good Grounds be prevented; therefore I shall order my Army and my Generals to act on the Defensive only till you can give me better Reasons for carrying on the War.”

All this is said upon a Supposition that what the Scdalous Sribler of false News hath Printed. But can any Man believe the Account? Is it Rational to think that Prince Engene is so lit∣tle a Man of Breeding as to give the British General such Language? Ought not the Writer of such News to be brought to the Whipping-Post for thus abusing Prince Eugene? Is it in the least likely that Prince Eugene would
have asked the Duke of Ormond so Insolent a Question on his giving his Opinion against Fighting, as, What do you do here then? Every General has his Liberty in the Council of War to give his Opinion to what shall be there pro∣pos'd for or against Fighting: Prince Eugene would not have made that Re∣ply to any Private Colonel, as to say, What do you do here then? But had not his Grace many a ready Answer to have re∣turned to such an Insult as that? Might he not have said, “That the Troops of his Mistress were there, and had been there Nine Year, to give his Master a Crown, which he had neither Ability to gain without them, nor Graude to acknow∣ledge to his Benefactress now he had got it?” Might he not have replied, They were to fight when they saw Occasion, but not like Auxiliaries, to fight at his bid∣ding? Might be not have said, They were there to fight when Probable Oc∣casions presented, and when Evident Ad∣vantage presented, but not Alamode de Blaregnies, to sacrifice the Lives of a Brave Body of Men to the Glory of a Gene∣ral, and to butcher their Men for the meer Name of a Victory, as was done at Malplacquet? Many more Just Returns might have been given to a Sarcasm, so Haughty and so Rude as that; but our General contented him∣self
to give no other Reply than to shew his Orders; and this may be a very good Reason for any Wise Men to be∣lieve no such Affront was offered to him; for all that know the Duke know this of him, that he does not want Fire in his Temper to resent such an Affront.

But here it is fit that we observe how Villainous the Party Her Majesty has to do with at Home are in their very Na∣ture, who rather than not form something to enflame their Party, will publish such gross Forgeries, and put Affronts of the Grossest Nature upon their own Friends, and Men of the Greatest Rank in the World: It is also the kindest and best Construction that can be put upon this Affair, to say that it is a Forgery of the News-writers here, set on Work by a Party who have Designs against the Queen's Interest, and that of her Allies also; for if it were true in Fact, if Prince Eugene did actually Send such a Message to the Duke of Ormond, or ask him such a Question upon his giving his Opinion a∣gainst attacking the French. is it not a very good Reason why Her Majesty should give such Orders? Is it not high Time the Queen should be Mistress of Her own Troops, and of Her own Part in the War also? Indeed had there been no o∣ther Dispute or Dissatisfaction between them before, yet such a Passage happening, the
Duke of Ormond ought never to have encamped in one Line with them after it. This proves to any Considering Per∣son to what a Degree of Subjection to our Haughty Allies the Ministry of late Years had brought our Affairs, and how till now we were to be called out when∣ever the Hirelings of the Foreign Prin∣ces pleas'd to demand it, and to attack at whatever Expence of Blood, and with whatever Disadvantage. Nothing can be a greater Justification to the Measures now taking than the Insolence of the Allies to us, not on this Occasion only, but on many other Occasions, and also of the dangerous Correspondence carry'd on be∣tween some People Abroad, whose Obli∣gations to Her Majesty call for other Things from them; and a Party at Home, who avowedly espouse and justifie the giving us all into the Hands of the Dutch; and that we are not to be trusted with our own Peace, but ought to take it at a Se∣cond Hand, as the Dutch please to make it for us. Will any contend that we should not now open our Eyes, and that we should not now act by our own Coun∣cils? Will they still suppose us in our Non-age and Pupil-age, that we must be led about Blindfold, and be made Tools and Engines to the Dutch Avarice and Imperial Ambition? The Party here, to cover the Eyes of their Followers, have
now taken a New Course in this Matter, to stile ad Compiains against our Allies, and to make is Obvious so much as to compla of the Dutch, or of the hardest and most unjust Treatment from them, or from any other of the Allies; they are Industrious to spread Reports that Her Majesty seeks Occasions against the Dutch, and that we are all driving into a War with the Dutch, as if we could be in no Alliance with them, but such a one in which they must be allowed to give the Law to our Conduct, and make their Markets of us, by putting the most Shameful Tricks upon us, and managing us to gain on their Crutches, or rather carry them on our Shoulders; this has been no New Practice; some Men had Eyes to see it before, tho' now 'tis con∣fest it becomes more undeniably Public by their own Usage of the British Nation, according to the following Lines out of a Ballad of their own making, at the Treaty of Nimeguen, when the Dutch played as many false Cards as they have done now.

LG.L: The Whigs lately put out the Nation to Nurse,
With an Old Wooden Leg and a Crutch,
And to teach us to Go, ty'd our Leading-strings too,
And gave them to hold to the Dutch.
The Dutch, as who would not, that understood Trade,
Brought us up heavy Burthens to ;
And as we grew weak, they doubled our Pack,
And laid on the Weight of the War.
Like Isachar's Ass, we couch'd to the Load,
And carry'd our Burthen so true;
The Dutch tho't we had been so beat to the Road,
We should be their Pack-Horse quite thro',
But some Ages of Light have clear'd up our Sight,
And now from our Tutelage breaking,
We think we're at Age for ourselves to engage,
And the Peace may be of our own making.

DIV1.P:
This is the true State of the Dutch Management, which many People, who formerly were hard to believe, are now forward to inform themselves of; for the Sakof these it may be very fit to have the tru Source of the present Case laid open, an when the Plot is more fully discovered, Knavery of the Parties will be more eviden for it is not hard to perswade any one believe that all this Sr is not made witho some beginning, and without many preous Intrigues and aballings of the Pa here with their Friends at the Hague▪ a this brings us back to the Treaty of Pea and the Conduct of the Party in Engla It is mentioned above how when the Imrialists
found a Treaty of Peace unavoida∣ble, and that Her Britannic Majesty prest it so earnestly, that it would go on without them, if they did not think fit to come in; they at last complied, and how, after their having so complied their Application, turn'd immediately to counter-act the Pro∣gress of the Treaty, that so, tho' they could not interrupt the beginning, they might disappoint the end of a Treaty, and bring on the War by the necessary Consequence; what were the Measures they took to bring this to pass is obvious to every ordinary View; and how far they obtain'd their End, as they thought, is evident also; the Armies being already in the Field, while the Negotiations at Ʋtrecht were at a full stand, by the insisting upon Answers in writing from the French Plenipotentiaries, instead of entring into a Treaty by Confe∣rence, as was first intended; during the whole Negotiation at Ʋtrecht, the Parties in England and in Holland spread about Re∣ports, and positively affirmed, that the Bri∣tish Court had made a Separate Peace with France; and even the Memorials from some of the Foreign Ministers signified as much; the Party from hence assur'd them Abroad so constantly of it, that all Means possible were made use of to put a Stop to the Ne∣gotiations, that they might bring the Bri∣tish Ministers Abroad to declare themselves; but they were too penetrating for the other
to break into their Councils, till the other thought of this Experiment, which, as a Great Man among the Party here said, could not fail, and this was their last Resort, viz. that the Armies should join, and that a Motion should be made, whatever the Po∣sture of Affairs might be, to attack the French Army in their Camp, and force them to a Battle; then, said they, you produce the desired Effect, let it fail either Way; for if the British General Fights, we shall either Conquer or be Defeated, if we Con∣quer the Treaty of Peace is at End, if we are Defeated the Ministry in England are Ruined, and so we shall Conquer that Way. On the other Hand, if the British General will not Fight then they discover themselves that they have made a Se∣parate Peace; that these have been the Methods of the Party, and the Steps they have taken, they may deny if they think fit; but the publishing them here will serve to convince them that their Measures are not quite so Impenetrable, or their private Resolves so well Concerted and Concealed, as they slatter themselves to believe.

Now it may appear also, that altho' these Things promised a sure Event equal to the Expectation of the Contrivers, yet their Po∣liticks have failed at this Time, the British Councils have thought fit to countermine all this Plot; First, they have not been so Dupe as to be drawn into the Snare of Fight∣ing,
and engage the Enemy with a Confe∣deracy, who had some Views which made it less Essentaial than at another Time, whether they were Victors, or not: Here the Match was not equal; for the Victory only was the British General's Safety, the only Security of his Mistress, the Queen, and of the whole Nation▪ whereas a Defeat, however fatal to us, was not entirely with∣out some Prospects that render'd it less fatal in its Consequences to some People than at other Times; for, fay these Men, one Blow would Ruin all the New Scheme, and Restore Affairs, set up the Old Ministry again, and break all the Measures of the British Court. This is the Foundation up∣on which, as is said, some were so open to say, “They knew not how to keep the Fast that was appointed by Her Majesty for the Success of the War, for they did not know whether they had best pray for Victory or no;” nay, a known Citizen of London, whose Name is no Secret, was pleased to say openly, “He did not know but that if we were a little beaten it might be for our Good at this Time;” let any one that knows and sees these Things, judge Impartially, whe∣ther, while such a Temper is reigning a∣mong us, it would consist with the Wisdom and Penetration of Her Majesty and Her Council to venture a Battle, either as joined with such Allies Abroad, or surrounded with such Private Enemies at Home, but by
the Wisdom of the British Councils we have countermined this Plot; and now they find themselves all disappointed, for they can neither bring the Army to run Headlong into an Engagement, nor have they yet made themselves Masters of our Measures; this Wisdom however they have learnd by it, viz. that the British Affairs are no more in Foreign Management; that if they will end the War Honourably, and make a Firm, Lasting, Peace, they may have the Concurrence of the British Court for the Advantage of all their Interests, and for the procuring to them a Just and Reasonable Satisfaction; but that the Bri∣tish Nation are not to be Bullied into the War, as another said the Emperor would not be Bullied into the Peace.

There are the true Plans of this Affair, and now it seems as if they are come to such a Head, that they must be brought to an Issue one Way or other; the British Court have desired a Fair Treaty, that an Honourable Peace might be obtained for all Parties▪ the Obstinacy of a few encou∣couraged from hence, and prompted at Vienna, have done their utmost to prevent that Peace being General; and as if they had insulted our Court upon it, they had brought it to this Point, which was spoken openly at the Hague; “We will take Care they shall not make a General Peace, and let them make a Separate Peace if they dare: If they
have now push'd on that Notion so far as they can, should Great-Britain make such a Peace as Her own Safety requires, they may see Cause to blame themselves; for tho' the Queen of Great-Britain has been very far from desiring to make Her own Peace exclusive from Her Allies, yet no good Subject of Her Majesty can patiently hear the Tools of the present Parties, or the Emissaries of those who oppose this Peace, insult Her as being afraid to se∣cure Herself and Her own People: If a Sepa∣rate Peace shall be the Result of the Obsti∣nacy of those whose Interests are made wilfully to oppose Her Majesty, the Conse∣quences lye at their Door; Her Majesty is not to be insulted by Prince Eugen, or any one else, as if She was afraid to pursue Her own Measures, or afraid to own what She has proposed: The Intrigue is of Necessity to be now made Publick, the Measures taken on both Sides will now appear, yea, they do appear: The Plot is against a Peace; not against this or that Condition of Peace, but against Peace in General; the Transaction is double, let us see the dark Sides of both.

The Emperor is positive against a Peace, his Reason is plain and undeniable; his is the Gain of the War; all that hath been fought for, or all that is contended for in the War, or in the Peace, is for him: While the Contention is carrying on, what is it he
possesses? He receives the whole Revenues of the Electorate of Bavaria, and of the Dutchy of Mantua, the large Contributions levyed upon the State of Genoa, the Grand Duke of Tuscany, many of the Territories of the Pope, the State of Venice, and the other Princes of Italy, this he puts into the Impe∣rial Treasury for the Support of his War, whilst yet it is depending; and all this is, besides the Possession of such Parts of the Spanish Monarchy as are obtaind for him, with the Blood, and at the Expence, of the Confederates; such are the Provinces of the Low Countries, the Rich Dutchy of Milan, the Kingdom of Naples, the Principality of Cata∣lognia, &c. except only the Expence of the Em∣peror in gaining and maintaining the Possessi∣on of the last of these Places. Two Things will appear eviden tin this, in which the true Rea∣son of the Emperors desiring the Continuance of the War may be found. 1. That except the Kingdom of Naples, the Conquests of all those Countries are the Effect of the Treasure, as well as Power, of the Confe∣derates, and have been reduced chiefly at their Expence. 2. That the prodigious Re∣venues of those several Countries put much more Money into the Coffers of the Em∣peror than has been expended by him in the Support of the War, (the present Year excepted,) and has gone plenteously into the Coffers of the great Officers, Courtiers, and the great Army of Depndants, who
always hang on upon the Imperial Courts, whose Voratious Avarice not the whole Monarchy of Spain, no, or of the World, can satisfie. This is that which has so many Years been the Complaint of other Nations as the true Reason why no Peace could be made in Hungaria; not all the Confederates could prevail by the most pressing Importunities upon the Imperial Court to grant Peace to the Poor Distressed Protestants, because the Courtiers and Clergy at Vienna had gotten such large Possession of the Revenues and Estates of the Malecontents, which they knew on the close of the Troubles they must be obliged to refund, and which they resolved never to part with so long as they could be detain∣ed, that the Miseries of that Countrey could never find an End, but in Conquest and Depopulation: And such hath been the Devastation in that poor Kingdom, that they have not now People left to fill and cultivate the Land, in a Place, once the most Populous Countrey of Europe, for which Reason they now invite the Boors of Suabia to go and settle there, that the Landlords may have Tenants to occupy their Lands: This is a most Remarkable Event, a Thing no War with the urks could ever bring to pass, altho' those Wars are very Desolating also.

Come we next to the other Bran of the Opposers of Peace, as such; the the
Party at Home here among ourselves; i needeth very little Cunning to or Penetration to dive, into the Reasons of the Opposition made Peace; that is to say, the violent Oppo∣sition of Parties; the Case is so Nakd any Eye may see it; the Dispute here is all for Management and Superiority; the New Ministry propose putting an End to the War; the Outed Party see, that if the Peace is made the New Ministry will be established by that Means, and be be∣yond the Power of them and their Interest to shake them; they apply therefore with all their Might to oppose a Peace, as that in which they find the Ruin of their Party infallibly contained.

Hitherto the Opposers of Peace are un∣derstood of those who oppose it not on Account of the Conditions, but as a Peace; the other Allies, as the Dutch the Duke of Savoy, the King of Partugal, &c. these are supposed only to have their Views at the Conditions on which a Peace may be obtained, such as the Possession of a Barrier in Flanders, a Tariff of Trade, and the like, for the Dutch; the Recovery of Savoy, and Security of the Posts and Vallies to the Savoyard; the Articles of the late Treaty, and the Affairs of Brasil to the Portugal; these Things granted, these Allies would be soon reconciled to a Peace, not regarding who, or by what
lands it was made; but with the other t is not so: The strict and newly settled Confederacy between the former Poten∣tate, and a Party here, has no Dificulty in it, after the Reasons why they respe∣ctively are obliged to oppose all Peace, as such, are thus examined; if there is any Thing Wderful in the Conjunction, it must be to see a Sovereign Court of the First Magnitude, a Head, containing the First Figure in the Christian World, stoop∣ing to concert Measures with a Faction, and to support a Disaffected Party, whose Views are not only contemptible, but are obnoxious to, and the Aversion of, their Sovereign; omenting a Distracted, Outed, and Desperate Party, against their Prince, and against a Prince to whom the said Court are under Insinite Obligations; to whose Kindness and Generosity the Emperor very much owes the Crown he enjoys. This may give some Surprize to the World, though, as Things go among some Confeerated People, no∣thing is to be esteemed Wonderful; nor is there any Thing so strange in the World but it may be expected from these People, except it be that very Nw and Unknown Thing, of which Authors have lately en∣deavoured to make some Description, called Imperial Grvtitude.

Having thus a little enquired into the several Circumstances, which have brought
the Publick Matters to their present State, it will serve the better to explain the other Phaenomena of Managmen which remain: Can any wonder or reflect that having to do with an enraged Faction, and with Foreign Powers, who, how∣ever differently moved, concur in project∣ing the Destruction of their Countrey, and aim at carrying on the War which must end in the General Calamity; the British Court should take Measures to de∣feat tis Danger us Principle, and to dis∣appoint the Cruel and Bloody Projects of those who value not the Blood of Millions of People, so their private Interests and Designs are carried on: To this Purpose, finding the Opposition to all Publick Trea∣ties carried on with so much Malicious Vi∣olence, and a Confederacy of Interests op∣posing the true In of Her Majesty's Subjects, it became absolutely necessary to take such Masues, as that the posi∣tive Interest of Britain may be secured, whether those People think sit to join, or no; at the same Time actually doing Right to the whole Confederacy, and leaving them full Space to find their Account in it, who are not infatuated by Heaven for their own Punishment and Destruction: This, however wholesome for the whole Body, admitted not of being done so, as that those, who, for the Reasons above, were bent to circumvent and destroy all Attempts
towards healing the Wounds of Europe, might be in a Conition to practice upon it, as they had done before. This the Party here make loud Complaints of, and hence began the popular Reports, and individuons Complaints, that there was a Private Clandestine Treaty carried on with France to the Prejudice of the Alliance, and without the Concurrence of the Con∣federates, contrary to the Grand Alliance, and in Prejudice of the several Powers con∣cerned in the War with France; whereas, were this rightly examined, the Truth of the Case is no more than this, that a Party Prepossession being entred into the Heads of those People, who ought to have been bet∣ter Judges of the Publick Good, and almost every Branch of the Confederacy having in their Turn either acted in Prejudice of the British Interest, or stood still, and suf∣fered themselves to be made Parties to those that did so, the Queen of Great-Britain was obliged to take Her Interest, and that of Her Kingdoms, into Her own Hands, and having at the same Time a due Regard to the Safety and Security of Her Allies, and especially an exact Eye upon the Stipu∣lations of Her Leagues and Confederacies with others, to attempt by Herself the re∣storing the Tranquility of Europe.

It is no more to be wonder'd at, that all the Parties who having hitherto made their Merchandise of this Nation, and who
thought we were the Dupes of their Pro∣jects and Schemes, of whom they were still to make Advantage, were secretly Nettled and Restless when they saw themselves di∣vested of the Influence they formerly had over our Affairs, than it might be won∣der'd at, that a Man having gain'd a great Prize from another, should be unwilling to part with it again; they had no Re∣course but to Clamours and incessant Rail∣ing at the British Management, unjustly reproaching the Queen with having be∣tray'd the Alliance, that is to say, having rescued Herself and Her Nation from being made a Prey to Ten Friends, under Pretence of reducing One Enemy; it has been their especial Grievance, that Her Majesty hath been obliged, in Her own Defence, to ex∣pose to the World the Scandalous Usage She hath had from these Her Allies: Tne Deficiency of their Quota's, the Fallacious Construction of their several Conventions and Agreements made for mutual Assist∣ance, the Weak and Unjust Pretences they have made use of to excuse or extenuate their not supplying Money, Troops, Ships, &c. in due Proportions to what Her Majesty has done; these Things they hoped to have concealed, and to have thus carried on the Game of the War to such length as might have served their own Ends; in which it appears too evident, that Britain had al∣ways the labouring Oar, viz. the Expence
without the Advantage under this Usage, the Government at present suffers, and the Queen being happily restored to search the Bottom of Things, and, as above, taking the Management of Her own Peace into Her own Hands, it is scarce Credible, nor will Posterity believe it, what Treatment Her Majesty meets with, as well from Her Allies Abroad, as more especially from a Furious and Raging Party at Home; what Reproaches on Her Peron, and on those who are thought fi to be entrusted in Her Affairs; Ministers of State have often been Maligned and Maltreated, and as often for faithful doing their Duty as for any Thing; but never were any treated like these; never did any Prince bear such Indignities in the Persons of Her Servants as Her Ma∣jesty now does, and all this too upon bare Supposition; before the Issue of Things is brought on, before Things are come to Con∣clusions, or the Matters of Fact appear.

The Design of this is rather to search in∣to the Practice of the Enemies of our Peace, than to vindicate Her Majesty, or Her Mi∣nistry; they want no Aid of that Kind, the Issue of Things will be their Vindication: They go on steadily with their Designs in Defiance of all these, giving us still Hopes that all will issue in the Publick Good, and in that Firm, Lasting, Peace which Europe wants so much, and wih these very Men are to be happy in so much oppose
it, and malign the Government for endea∣ouring to make it.

The Intrigues of these People bring us down, as before, directly to the Case now so exclaim'd against, viz.) the Queen ha∣ving given Her Generals Order not to act offensively against France; and what can the Enemies of the Public Peace say to this? Had not Her Majesty done this, all their Con∣trivances, and all the Intrigues at Ʋtrecht, the Hague, and elsewhere, had been brought to Perfection, and their Plot had had its desired Effect; it has all along ap∣pear'd to those who have had the least Power of searching into these Affairs, that the Designs of those People, who pretend∣ed to meet at a Treaty, were only to delay and spin out the Negotiations in length, loading the Treaties with Difficulties, and starting unreasonable Scruples and Ob∣jections, that the Season advancing, and the Time for Action coming on, the Ar∣mies might be in the Field, and the War might have succeeded.

According to this Plot they went on, they obtain'd to impose the De∣mand of Answers in writing upon the French, which they knew gave the usual advantage to the Treay, by which for∣mer Treaties just to a Piod of doing came on▪ they have been
micably adjusted, and by which the Plenipote∣iaries might soonest have come into the Bottom of the Respective Demands, and so have directly treated on the Whole, by which a speedy Conclu∣ion might have been made, either for Peace or War, which was the true Intent and Meaning of Her Majesty in obtaining a Treaty: But these People to whom the Thoughts of Peace was hate∣ful, as the Thing itself appear'd Fatal to their Mea∣sures, opposed all the Just Measures taken to bring Things thus to a Conclusion, building all their Hopes upon this Supposition, that if they could bring the Armies toether, the War must go on of Course; it is astonishing to think these People should be so weak to believe that the Queen of Great Britain should send Ministers of so little Penetration to the Treaty, that they should not see when they were thus trifled with; or that they should think when it was seen, and discovered, Her Majesty should not take effectual Measures to pre∣vent them; that they should imagine that such Dealing was not in the highest Manner disobliging, and that when it should be discovered it would not serve to open the Eyes of Her Majesty's Subjects, and fill them with just Indignation at seeing their Sove∣reign, and the whole Nation, in so gross a Manner abused; but be that as it will, they have not, Thanks be to God, found the British Court so easie, or so at a loss, to take their own Measures, Her Majesty having soon resolved not to leave Her Ambas∣sadors and Servants there to be thus treated, ordered the Earl of Strafford to come away, and has, by o∣ther Hands, given the States Occasion to know how She has Reason to resent this Treatment.

And yet what is it this Resentment amounts to? Hitherto it amounts to little more than Negatives, viz. No to gratifie the Deigns of those who would either prorract the Wa declaredly, by refusing the most Just Conditions of Peace, or Artificially, by pushing Her Majesty upon prosecuting the War even before it had been tried whether the Enemy would yield to Honourable Terms, or no;” to let them see therefore that Her Majesty is not to be used as
She has been any longer, and that whatever they think fit to do in the Affair, Her Majesty ought not to be obliged to take Her Measures them, more especially when it is so evident that those Measures are so directly contrary to the true esign of the War, and the General Good of Europe; for these Reasons Her Majesty has thought fit to forbid Her General joining in carrying on an Offensive War; at the same Time letting the Allies know, that Her Majesty having Reason to think Herself ill used in the Affair of the Treaty, and that all Parties did not come thither equally disposed to bring the said Trea∣ty to the Happy desired Conclusion of an Honoura∣ble Peace, that therefore Her Majesty finds Herself obliged to take Care of the Safety and Peace of Her own Dominions, and of the Happiness and Interest of Her own Subjects, already sufficiently exhausted by the length of the War, as well as by the unequal Share of the Burthen which they have hitherto borne, and which has very unjustly been put upon the Al∣lies, and unwarily submitted to by those whom Her Majesty has formerly entrusted with the Di∣rection of those Affairs.

And let any Impartial Considering Man tell us what could Her Majesty do less, in common Justice to Her Faithful Subjects, whose Presures have been so great, and who have so chearfully▪ so long, and so patiently, borne the Burden of this war? Had Her Majesty found Her Allies sincerely disposed to a Treaty, and to enter into the particular Demands for nogotiating a Public and General Peace, it is certain that the Queen of Great-Britain was heartily and entirely bent to have procured a general Satis∣faction to all the Allies, and was disposed to have concerned Herself in their Safety and Interest equally with Her own; but finding Herself treated as a∣bove, She is justified before God and Man in taking Care of the Interests of Her own People, leaving those who Delight in War to carry it on by them∣selves, till Time, and their own Experience, shall open their Eyes.
